manifests/api.pp.message: IIUC these are for configuring the driver agent so I agree with previous comments that these should probably go in a separate file. I'm not opposed to them being in puppet-octavia but unless this is configuring the API server, it belongs elsewhere. With respect to each provider having their own packaging - we *could* take that approach but there is precedent for collocating *config stuff* under one puppet roof. Neutron for example... if the intent also is to backport this stuff - new packages probably will be harder to pull off. type: "raw":

The octavia container is IP'd so flat network type does not apply, raw it better used in the context

group binds neutron_linuxbridge_agent: 

neutron_linuxbridge_agent are already bound to neutron_agents_container which manages the DHCP server for the lbaas management network as it gets added as regular neutron network

This information is better placed in the release notes and documentation, leaving the log warning concise and useful. In addition to shortening the log warning we also hacked the enforcer in keystone to stop repeating these messages in the logs. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1836568 for more info.
that's true. we will have reno and spec doc for details updates about "why". Let me update it to one line.

I'm not just talking about the unit tests. This is what the logs look like with this deprecation warning:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/788989/

The multi-line warnings are repeated for each deprecated rule. And the warnings are reemitted every time the policy is reloaded. There's no need for a paragraph of prose to be repeated so often in the logs.

yeah we disabled those warning already. faced the failure for that and no more warning for testing side
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676670/

This is a little confusing, because you are actually deprecating these rules but they are now defined twice, here and in the deprecated_rules below. Instead of modifying the new system_* rules, it would be better to use deprecated_for_removal on these existing rules. Furthermore, it would be best not to deprecate them at all while the nova code itself is still using them since operators can do nothing about it if nova is using it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Needs more of a comment to explain why this is needed.

(Memory says we saw a lock-up in the previous code version.)

I submitted the patch long time ago, just because the code is simply not working. Naveen reverted my patch, which I don't think that is "good". I would say, even with today's latest upstream, the code is still not working.

Today in latest upstream, the only function which is draining the self.external_devices queue is maybe_ensure_external_devices(), and maybe_ensure_external_devices() is only called when there is new port being added to etcd. Which means, when eventlet detected a new tap interface in Linux, the interface will be added to the queue via _consider_external_device(), but nothing will happen after that.

In summary, the fix is needed otherwise when tap interface is added post port binding (like DHCP or L3 router port), it will not work.

-1: This code is not very readable, and is not taking into account comments.

I think it's easier to read, and also removes comments, if we do something like:

    with open("/proc/mounts", "r") as mounts:
        # Remove empty lines and split lines by whitespace
        lines = [l.split() for l in mounts.read().splitlines() if l.strip()]

        # Return {mountpoint: mountdevice}.  Fields 2nd and 1st as per
        # http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/fstab.5.html
        return {line[1]: line[0] for line in lines if line[0] != '#'}

Sorry for confusing you! My thoughts hopped way ahead of my fingers. This is what I wanted to express.

It is indeed true, that Nova generates network_data.json let alone the rest of the  metadata. Arguably, validating Nova-generated JSON is marginally reasonable because Nova never fails (hm-hm) and no human soul is involved in metadata  generation process.

However, there are tools in the wild such as ironic or Glean that piggyback Nova metadata format for their own good. These tools might be able to accept network_data.json from the Operator - this is where things can go South.

The main driver for creating the schema being proposed is to harden ironic against human error when Nova is not involved (the topmost use-case being DHCP-less or L3-only bare metal deploy).

We can probably stash this schema somewhere within ironic or Glean, however I thought it would be best to have the schema under Nova control as the only source of truth.

Thanks for the explanation, it helped me a lot. I agree with Stephen that we need some way to test the schema against nova emitted network_data. Thanks for the analysis. Please, read my comment at 11:43. I was wrong reading the logs. isbas() do not call realpath(), this method is called in the generator raising the exception [1]

`isabs` just return if arg `startswith` start with file separator [1]

Ahhh no, this is not the method affected. That was a mistake reading the logs. The method which can raise this exception is os.path.realpath() [1]

Try to execute this with the debugger enabled.
path='log/fistro'
print(os.path.realpath(path))

If you call this script from a directory (not the one containing this script) and before executing the second line you delete this directory, then you'll have this exception.

This is easier with Pycharm, for example, where you can define the working directory (what os.getcwd() will return) and you can set breaking points.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/oslo_rootwrap/filters.py#L131

Caution, it's never raised because you should test the following scenario:

- create a dir;
- move to this one during execution;
- delete this dir during execution;
- try to call isabs

The issue here is that if the path is not an absolute path then posixpath try to return one by calling `os.getcwd()` [3] to join to arg given and return a normalized path.

You tested the following scenario which is not the same of the previously described and fixed by Rodolfo:

```
# (`/tmp/boom` doesn't exist locally)
python2.7 -c "import os;print(os.path.isabs('/tmp/boom'))"
True
python3.6 -c "import os;print(os.path.isabs('/tmp/boom'))"
True
python3.7 -c "import os;print(os.path.isabs('/tmp/boom'))"
True
python3.8 -c "import os;print(os.path.isabs('/tmp/boom'))"
True
```

Even by calling the posixpath [2] module directly to emulate the behavior described in [1] I can't reproduce the issue:

```
python3.6 -c "import posixpath;print(posixpath.abspath('/tmp/boom'))"
/tmp/boom
```

This work because I don't remove my current working directory during execution.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/789807/
[2] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.6/Lib/posixpath.py#L376,L385
[3] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.6/Lib/posixpath.py#L381

specs/train/remove-puppet.rst.message: we'll need to make sure the `no_log` keyword is used in sensitive ansible tasks.
Done

Adding the ANSIBLE_LOG_PATH environment variable will instruct ansible to create a specific log file of a given task/playbook run. If we get something like this into the openstack client we could potentially provide a more robust runtime log by default; without having to capture everything from a shell command and redirecting it to a file. This could potentially give operators and deployers better insight in their clouds without out any additional overhead.
I think this is potentially huge.

Given this is being defined as a multi-cycle effort I'm not sure these works items are needed or relevant. What we work on is bound to change over the cycles. We could probably track most of this on StoryBoard in a single project, with multiple worklists.

Because it relies on Hiera & puppet-nova, which are both proposed to be removed here.

My proposal is that we keep the interface which allows the override of any parameter, where ExtraConfig will be the first source of truth so we can override anything.

+1

I see no value for TripleO in *creating* and maintaining (on our own) the same features that puppet openstack modules provide today. I'd fully support this proposal, if it is explicitly rephrased to something like "create as less new code as possible, while reuse as much of the existing (like OpenStack-Ansible) as possible".

I'll quote what Alex Schultz wrote in an email recently:

"We will likely not switch to using openstack ansible modules. Nor would we use kolla-ansible. Primarily because backwards compatibility. Additionally the only thing we need from them would be configuration generation.  The orchestration and ordering thing is completely tripleo at this point and that's one of those things where we have addressed bugs and the idiosyncrasies of openstack over time.  Don't get me wrong I'm all for sharing the load with other projects and improving the overall quality, however everyone seems to be talking about using these other projects and I'm not seeing folks step up to actually do the community liaison work."

This specs is about evaluation a possible option; with the end goal of simplifying TripleO. If our conclusion doesn't meet this goal, we'll simply abandon this idea.
Is there a plan to provide migration scripts?

I understand the pain for us, but considering the number of users who would have existing templates and wanted to deploy latest version or upgrade the environment, would benefit from migration scripts. Like the one we have for nic config migration, it is/was really valuable.

Lets see if we could find any automated way, based on the below discussion.

you mean a script which would port something like "nova::compute::reserved_host_memory" into nova.conf/DEFAULT/reserved_host_memory ?

The mapping would be very long to maintain (hundreds and hundreds of parameters), I'm not sure we really want to do that.

What do you think? Should we do that?

Or we can use nova_config directly:

    parameter_defaults:
      ComputeExtraConfig:
        nova::config::nova_config:
            DEFAULT/reserved_host_memory:
                value: some_value


However have to be careful not to set a param that is already handled by puppet-tripleo/puppet-nova or we get duplicate declaration errors.

Do we avoid this with the new approach? I suppose we don't need to use puppet nova_config, can just step in after running puppet and alter the conf file (using ansible-config_template?).

I like this proposal, I've seen customers using this interface already.
We could support that syntax with Ansible where we would have a mapping between nova::config::nova_config and the actual config file.

e.g. nova::config::nova_config points to /etc/nova/nova.conf

And when processing the ExtraConfig we would transform:

    parameter_defaults:
      ComputeExtraConfig:
        nova::config::nova_config:
            DEFAULT/reserved_host_memory:
                value: some_value

into

    parameter_defaults:
      ComputeExtraConfig:
        /etc/nova/nova.conf:
            DEFAULT:
              reserved_host_memory: some_value

Is it possible to hide this from the user? In case of neutron, there are lots of config files - neutron.conf, ml2_confi.ini, openvswitch_agent.ini, sriov_agent.ini

Expecting user to know and provide those details, reduces the usability and increases complexity. I don't know if it is possible, but if this information is hidden or derived in the ansible role, it will be easy to use.
ah yes, +1

I think we also need to specify which service/container it applies to. Services can share config_data (nova and libvirt do) so it probably needs to be something like:

    parameter_defaults:
      ComputeExtraConfig:
        nova_libvirt: # puppet config_volume used by the nova_compute service
          /etc/nova/nova.conf:
            DEFAULT:
              reserved_host_memory: some_value

indeed.

do you think an alternative name would help?
like:

  sriov_agent

would be mapped to

  /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/sriov_agent.ini

I am thinking out loud to see if it make sense.

Why do we need <Role>Extraconfig?
It was introduced to provide direct puppet configuration on the role (node) overriding global parameters. 

Do we have alternatives?
* role-specific parameters [1] <Role>Parameters can provide the same overriding capability managed by Heat
* puppet parameters which are not exposed via Heat can also be configured directly,like nova::cpu_allocation_ratio, for which there no alternative, other than adding the parameter to heat.

Can we retire ExtraConfig?
* Given that we are removing puppet and moving towards ansible, which can provide vars grouping more conveniently than existing methods, I dont see any value in retaining ExtraConfig
* Backward Compatibility - Any we are asking users to migrate to the new format in the same parameter. Why not migrate to the heat based role-specific parameter?
* It also unifies multiple methods of parameter configuration to simpler ones, so that replacing heat would be much easier
* When puppet is being removed, why to have puppet specific configuration parameter

I see values in removing this parameter, does anyone has any other cases that might be solved with current approach? This way we can reduce our baggage and become thinner.


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-docs/latest/install/advanced_deployment/role_specific_parameters.html
missing colon for this and above lines?
yes, my bad

Should we need to consider the puppet for design? I believe the format should be compatible to ansible and should follow the ansible guidelines in defining those. In such a way, that it should be easy to remove heat at a later point. If that needs to be compatible with puppet, there should be temp workarounds, until it is removed, Or else puppet could run first and then ansible to apply extra configs, or some thing like it.

I didn't want to mix Puppet & Ansible when services are configured because of idempotency. If puppet modifies a config file and then Ansible adds extra params, then it removes idempotency which we don't want.

The way it could work is, we convert services by services and once a service can only be configured by either Puppet or Ansible; never both at the same time.

The list of converted services would be maintained so we know how to use ExtraConfig for them.

This is more appropriate. I have inferred the statement in the spec as that we are maintaining both for a certain time. I am fine with it, and it would be good, if you can depict above comment in the spec.

specs/stein/approved/destroy-instance-wi.message:
I still think this is the wrong place to do this. What you want to update is a specific volume attachment resource on the server, and I think the cleanest way to do that is via the existing PUT API:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=update-a-volume-attachment-detail#update-a-volume-attachment

The question is how to make that work when all you want to do is change the delete_on_termination value of an existing attachment, rather than swap for a new volume (which is all that API does today).

I think what we would probably do is:

1. make the volumeId parameter optional
2. add the delete_on_termination parameter

So if volumeId is specified, we're swapping volumes. If not, and delete_on_termination is specified, we're updating the delete_on_termination field for an existing BDM. Seems simple enough.
yes, this seems better, and really should combine the other spec together with this one, I saw that microversion is already 2.67 LOL
As Matt said, use the update a volume attachment API to update the ``delete_on_termination`` parameter, and combine the attach a volume to an instance API to this spec.
This title is a little confusing. Maybe it should be "Support for changing deleted_on_termination after boot?"
Yeah. This description is more accurate than before.
no, I can set that parameter when instance creation?

specs/stein/approved/support-deleting-da.message: Yeah, this doesn't seem relevant. The delete_on_termination flag during server create has been around since v2.0.
Yeah, this sentence can be removed, it doesn't make sense.

I'm not sure I'm following you here. You can specify the delete_on_termination flag in the block_device_mapping_v2 parameter, which is a list of dicts. The root volume is denoted with boot_index=0, but "data volumes" can be specified in that list as well with the boot_index field omitted meaning it's not a boot device. So it's possible to attach additional non-root volumes to the server at creation and mark them with delete_on_termination=True.

Isn't the point of this spec to allow passing delete_on_termination when attaching volumes *after* the server is created? So in this API?

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#attach-a-volume-to-an-instance
Agreed, this is already part of the server create API.

Yeah, this action put the servers create API is not suitable. I think it's okay to put it in the PUT /servers/{server_id} API.

 > Isn't the point of this spec to allow passing
 > delete_on_termination when attaching volumes *after* the 
 > server is created? So in this API? 

The attach-a-volume-to-an-instance API also need to add a microversion, so I think this need a new specs for this API to support delete_on_termination.

This has nothing to do with the server create API, as mentioned above. So you're suggesting to change the server *update* API to allow passing a list of volumes which should be deleted on termination?

Again, this can be done at server create time, and if anything it would seem more logical to add it to the volume attach API:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#attach-a-volume-to-an-instance

Or even this API:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#update-a-volume-attachment

But that's something completely different (that's the swap volume API and is admin-only by default).
None of the above, I will add this change to PUT /servers/{server_id} API.

Yeah, this will make the "volumeId" optional, if "volumeId" is None, it will be only update the delete_on_termination attribute, not all the block_device_mapping_v2 attributes.
This answers my question from L38.

This is where I'm confused. There's no block_device_mapping_v2 request parameter on the API today, so where will this come from? Are you saying you will add this request parameter as part of the new microversion?

And what about the already existing volumeAttachment request parameter? It's not optional in the API today.

specs/ussuri/approved/destroy-instance-w.message: Ah... so in this case snapshot fails because the compute node the instance use to live on doesn't exist? Although in my head I hoped a snapshot direct via Cinder would work, but maybe that requires detach?

I don't understand too much what you mean :(
But if the data volume has a snapshot in rbd and does not flatten when create the snapshot. Firstly, detach from the server by Cinder attachemts delete API while delete the server, then delete *that* data volume, because of the snapshot, the volume will be kept in Cinder.

Root volume issue will be recorded in the ``alternatives`` by Matt point.

It's probably worth noting here that you can't detach a root volume:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9742a64403c0a0ae5e0b37df5b0bf3ba14ac4626/nova/api/openstack/compute/volumes.py#L465

So if you boot from volume where nova creates the root volume and delete_on_termination=True when you created the server, but now you want to preserve the root volume after the server is deleted, you can't do that without updating the delete_on_termination field (this spec) or creating a snapshot of the server (which is probably an alternative to the root bdm issue here).
That is a good alternative.

Yeah, the alternative to the root bdm issue is better, that will be changed as follows:


Configure the ``delete_on_termination`` by the volume attach API (see [1]_),
if you want to change that value with the data volume, you could just detach
and re-attach with the new value.

If you boot from volume where nova creates the root volume and
``delete_on_termination=True`` when you created the server, but if you want
to preserve the root volume after the server is deleted, you can create a
snapshot of the server.

This indicates swap volume which is not the operation you want here, correct?

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#update-a-volume-attachment

I've mentioned this before on this review, but you really need to discuss the swap volume implications of solving this using the existing PUT /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id} API which until this proposal only deals with swap volume which is only supported by the libvirt driver.

I think PUT /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id} is likely the correct API if we do this change, but you need to discuss when this would be a simple update of the BDM record versus swapping the volume in the guest which is a much more complicated orchestration event (and admin-only by default) between nova and cinder. See the warning in the API reference about that.

So at a minimum, the volumeId body parameter - which is required today - would need to change to optional I think so you don't have to swap volumes to update the BDM for the attached volume represented by the volume_id in the URL path. And then what kind of validation happens with that, i.e. if volumeId in the body is optional and delete_on_termination in the body are optional, is it a 400 if neither are specified?

These are details that need to be thought through and documented in the spec before this is taken very seriously, and it's already a low priority spec given the alternatives are available for saving the volume (snapshot) or updating it (detach and re-attach non-root volumes with updated delete_on_termination value).

No, the volume_id in the path is required, it's how you identify the target volume attachment to update. It's the volumeId in the request body that is the volume you're swapping *to* if you're doing a swap volume today, but that would become optional with your spec so that you just update the volume denoted by the volume_id parameter in the *path* not the *body*.

> So at a minimum, the volumeId body parameter - which is
> required today - would need to change to optional I think so 
> you don't have to swap volumes to update the BDM for the 
> attached volume represented by the volume_id in the URL 
> path. And then what kind of validation happens with that, 
> i.e. if volumeId in the body is optional and 
> delete_on_termination in the body are optional, is it a 400 
> if neither are specified?

Yeah, I agree make the volume_id in URL path to optional, I am also concerned about this, I think we can make the following judgment:

# if volume_id not int the URL path, delete_on_termination and volumeId are all needed
* PUT /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/
  if (volumeId is None and delete_on_termination is not None) or
     (volumeId is not None and delete_on_termination is None) or
     (volumeId is None and delete_on_termination is None):
        raised 400

# we don't want to change the swap volume, so when volume_id was requested, the delete_on_termination cannot be set.
* PUT /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}
  if delete_on_termination is not None:
      raise 409

This seems complicated, so much so that I want to add a dedicated single API interface for data volume to reset the delete_on_termination to the server.
Yeah, it's a misunderstood, I got it now.

You could make this something we add to the delete instance call, thus avoiding the issues with the current attachment APIs? Unsure if people would prefer that? Specify ports and volumes that should be preserved after termination, regardless of what would normally happen? Or maybe just specify all ports and volumes survive.
As said above, I want to add a dedicated single API to deal with this. Or as Matt said, change the volume_id in the URL path to optional, then deal with this in different scenes.
DELETE doesn't take a body or any microversions and I don't think we want to start doing that.

This was also discussed at the Forum in Berlin:

Note the mention about how this could break Heat:

"This could break Heat if Heat created the volume, the user changed the flag and then nova deletes the volume but Heat expected it to exist."

I'm not sure how much of a concern that is though really, I would expect most people to use this API change to preserve a volume that otherwise would be deleted when the server is deleted and they changed their mind, not the other way around (started as delete_on_termination=False and then changed to True).
Adding "Discussed at the Forum in Berlin: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BER-bfv-improvements" to this References.

From the PoC code, I saw you update the RPC call. But I'm thinking we needn't that.

If we are dealing this in the API layer, I think we can not ensure the volume can attach to the target instance successfully. If we pass the parameter to "ComputeManger" by RPC call, we can ensure that we set the "delete_on_termination" of the new volume that was swapped, so I think it is safer to pass through RPC.

> But I prefer to not mix the swap and delete_on_termination together, to make the change easier.

Yes, it will be easier if we are limit the request parameters in the request body. But another problem is if we want to change the swap volume's ``delete_on_termination`` to TRUE, we will call this api do again, and it will also complicate the operation.

this seems updating 'delete_on_termination' for already attached volume but via PUT which is nothing but swap volume API not updating the existing attachment. 

I am not sure we need this. or we can just support 'delete_on_termination' for new volume only while swapping volume. 

I am curious why it was not done during supporting the same in POST /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id}
- https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack/nova/+spec/support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume

I think the main point of this spec is for being able to update an already existing attachment though, without having to detach/attach :\ (Brin, please correct me if I'm wrong).

Here is the place in the attach volume spec review where update of existing attachment was decoupled from the other work:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/612949/10/specs/train/approved/support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume.rst@37

My opinion is that allowing *only* update of an already existing attachment and not allowing specification of delete_on_termination for a new swap volume would be weird. And allowing *only* specification for a new swap volume is not what the spec use case is ultimately trying to get. For this reason, I think both should be supported if we bother to do this at all because the use case is mostly about the already existing attachment (if I understand correctly). It seems it would wasteful to do all the work to support specifying delete_on_termination only for a new swap volume when that is not what the use case wants the most.

I think overloading the PUT /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id} API to support being able to change the delete_on_termination value is not ideal, but it seems like the least ugly way to do it today in the absence of an overhaul of the swap volume API, as mentioned by lyarwood on IRC [1].

tests/fixtures/config/pass-to-parent/git.message:
by adding this, the unit test fails because now it doesn't use the parent-supplied secret, but used the secret that's provided to the job in here..

if i remove this, i get an invalid config, because a playbook with secrets that have and pass-to-parent set to false will just never make sense..

reference:
https://ad793cc4ef661bc84354-a22e2178400a1d74c0dfc0d0570ba9cf.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/708731/8/check/tox-py37/e3057dc/testr_results.html

tests/unit/test_v3.py.message:
I believe you should be able to adjust the checks here to verify that the parent playbook sees the parent secret, and the child playbook sees the child secret.

It's possible that once you do that, this test might duplicate another one, but I don't know off the top of my head.
